    <div class="docs markdown"><div align="center">

</div>

<a href="https://tuple.app/dotenv">
  <div>
    <img src="https://res.cloudinary.com/dotenv-org/image/upload/w_1000,ar_16:9,c_fill,g_auto,e_sharpen/v1756831704/github_repo_sponsorship_gq4hvx.png" width="600" alt="Tuple">
  </div>

<div class="pilwrap" id="dotenv">
  <h1>
    <a href="#dotenv" name="dotenv" class="pilcrow"></a>
dotenv <a href="https://www.npmjs.com/package/dotenv"><img src="https://img.shields.io/npm/v/dotenv.svg?style=flat-square" alt="NPM version"></a>
  </h1>
</div>
<img src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/motdotla/dotenv/master/dotenv.svg" alt="dotenv" align="right" width="200" />
<p>Dotenv is a zero-dependency module that loads environment variables from a <code>.env</code> file into <a href="https://nodejs.org/docs/latest/api/process.html#process_process_env"><code>process.env</code></a>. Storing configuration in the environment separate from code is based on <a href="https://12factor.net/config">The Twelve-Factor App</a> methodology.</p>
<p><a href="https://github.com/feross/standard"><img src="https://img.shields.io/badge/code%20style-standard-brightgreen.svg?style=flat-square" alt="js-standard-style"></a>
<a href="LICENSE.html"><img src="https://img.shields.io/github/license/motdotla/dotenv.svg" alt="LICENSE"></a>
<a href="https://codecov.io/gh/motdotla/dotenv-expand"><img src="https://codecov.io/gh/motdotla/dotenv-expand/graph/badge.svg?token=pawWEyaMfg" alt="codecov"></a></p>
<ul>
<li><a href="#-install.html">üå± Install</a></li>
<li><a href="#%EF%B8%8F-usage.html">üèóÔ∏è Usage (.env)</a></li>
<li><a href="#-manage-multiple-environments.html">üå¥ Multiple Environments üÜï</a></li>
<li><a href="#-deploying.html">üöÄ Deploying (encryption) üÜï</a></li>
<li><a href="#-examples.html">üìö Examples</a></li>
<li><a href="#-documentation.html">üìñ Docs</a></li>
<li><a href="#-faq.html">‚ùì FAQ</a></li>
<li><a href="./CHANGELOG.md.html">‚è±Ô∏è Changelog</a></li>
</ul>
<div class="pilwrap" id="install">
  <h2>
    <a href="#install" name="install" class="pilcrow"></a>
üå± Install
  </h2>
</div>
<pre><code class="bash">npm install dotenv --save
</code></pre>
<p>You can also use an npm-compatible package manager like yarn, bun or pnpm:</p>
<pre><code class="bash">yarn add dotenv
</code></pre>
<pre><code class="bash">bun add dotenv
</code></pre>
<pre><code class="bash">pnpm add dotenv
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="usage">
  <h2>
    <a href="#usage" name="usage" class="pilcrow"></a>
üèóÔ∏è Usage
  </h2>
</div>
<a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YtkZR0NFd1g">
<div align="right">
<img src="https://img.youtube.com/vi/YtkZR0NFd1g/hqdefault.jpg" alt="how to use dotenv video tutorial" align="right" width="330" />
<img src="https://simpleicons.vercel.app/youtube/ff0000" alt="youtube/@dotenvorg" align="right" width="24" />
</div>
</a>
<p>Create a <code>.env</code> file in the root of your project (if using a monorepo structure like <code>apps/backend/app.js</code>, put it in the root of the folder where your <code>app.js</code> process runs):</p>
<pre><code class="dosini">S3_BUCKET=&quot;YOURS3BUCKET&quot;
SECRET_KEY=&quot;YOURSECRETKEYGOESHERE&quot;
</code></pre>
<p>As early as possible in your application, import and configure dotenv:</p>
<pre><code class="javascript"><span class="hljs-built_in">require</span>(<span class="hljs-string">'dotenv'</span>).config()
<span class="hljs-built_in">console</span>.log(process.env) <span class="hljs-comment">// remove this after you've confirmed it is working</span>
</code></pre>
<p>.. <a href="#how-do-i-use-dotenv-with-import.html">or using ES6?</a></p>
<pre><code class="javascript"><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> <span class="hljs-string">'dotenv/config'</span>
</code></pre>
<p>ES6 import if you need to set config options:</p>
<pre><code class="javascript"><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> dotenv <span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> <span class="hljs-string">'dotenv'</span>

dotenv.config({ <span class="hljs-attr">path</span>: <span class="hljs-string">'/custom/path/to/.env'</span> })
</code></pre>
<p>That's it. <code>process.env</code> now has the keys and values you defined in your <code>.env</code> file:</p>
<pre><code class="javascript"><span class="hljs-built_in">require</span>(<span class="hljs-string">'dotenv'</span>).config()
<span class="hljs-comment">// or import 'dotenv/config' if you're using ES6</span>

...

s3.getBucketCors({<span class="hljs-attr">Bucket</span>: process.env.S3_BUCKET}, <span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">function</span>(<span class="hljs-params">err, data</span>) </span>{})
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="multiline-values">
  <h3>
    <a href="#multiline-values" name="multiline-values" class="pilcrow"></a>
Multiline values
  </h3>
</div>
<p>If you need multiline variables, for example private keys, those are now supported (<code>&gt;= v15.0.0</code>) with line breaks:</p>
<pre><code class="dosini">PRIVATE_KEY=&quot;-----BEGIN RSA PRIVATE KEY-----
...
Kh9NV...
...
-----END RSA PRIVATE KEY-----&quot;
</code></pre>
<p>Alternatively, you can double quote strings and use the <code>\n</code> character:</p>
<pre><code class="dosini">PRIVATE_KEY=&quot;-----BEGIN RSA PRIVATE KEY-----\nKh9NV...\n-----END RSA PRIVATE KEY-----\n&quot;
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="comments">
  <h3>
    <a href="#comments" name="comments" class="pilcrow"></a>
Comments
  </h3>
</div>
<p>Comments may be added to your file on their own line or inline:</p>
<pre><code class="dosini"># This is a comment
SECRET_KEY=YOURSECRETKEYGOESHERE # comment
SECRET_HASH=&quot;something-with-a-#-hash&quot;
</code></pre>
<p>Comments begin where a <code>#</code> exists, so if your value contains a <code>#</code> please wrap it in quotes. This is a breaking change from <code>&gt;= v15.0.0</code> and on.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="parsing">
  <h3>
    <a href="#parsing" name="parsing" class="pilcrow"></a>
Parsing
  </h3>
</div>
<p>The engine which parses the contents of your file containing environment variables is available to use. It accepts a String or Buffer and will return an Object with the parsed keys and values.</p>
<pre><code class="javascript"><span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> dotenv = <span class="hljs-built_in">require</span>(<span class="hljs-string">'dotenv'</span>)
<span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> buf = Buffer.from(<span class="hljs-string">'BASIC=basic'</span>)
<span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> config = dotenv.parse(buf) <span class="hljs-comment">// will return an object</span>
<span class="hljs-built_in">console</span>.log(<span class="hljs-keyword">typeof</span> config, config) <span class="hljs-comment">// object { BASIC : 'basic' }</span>
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="preload">
  <h3>
    <a href="#preload" name="preload" class="pilcrow"></a>
Preload
  </h3>
</div>
<blockquote>
<p>Note: Consider using <a href="https://github.com/dotenvx/dotenvx"><code>dotenvx</code></a> instead of preloading. I am now doing (and recommending) so.</p>
<p>It serves the same purpose (you do not need to require and load dotenv), adds better debugging, and works with ANY language, framework, or platform. ‚Äì <a href="https://github.com/motdotla">motdotla</a></p>
</blockquote>
<p>You can use the <code>--require</code> (<code>-r</code>) <a href="https://nodejs.org/api/cli.html#-r---require-module">command line option</a> to preload dotenv. By doing this, you do not need to require and load dotenv in your application code.</p>
<pre><code class="bash">$ node -r dotenv/config your_script.js
</code></pre>
<p>The configuration options below are supported as command line arguments in the format <code>dotenv_config_&lt;option&gt;=value</code></p>
<pre><code class="bash">$ node -r dotenv/config your_script.js dotenv_config_path=/custom/path/to/.env dotenv_config_debug=<span class="hljs-literal">true</span>
</code></pre>
<p>Additionally, you can use environment variables to set configuration options. Command line arguments will precede these.</p>
<pre><code class="bash">$ DOTENV_CONFIG_&lt;OPTION&gt;=value node -r dotenv/config your_script.js
</code></pre>
<pre><code class="bash">$ DOTENV_CONFIG_ENCODING=latin1 DOTENV_CONFIG_DEBUG=<span class="hljs-literal">true</span> node -r dotenv/config your_script.js dotenv_config_path=/custom/path/to/.env
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="variable-expansion">
  <h3>
    <a href="#variable-expansion" name="variable-expansion" class="pilcrow"></a>
Variable Expansion
  </h3>
</div>
<p>Use <a href="https://github.com/dotenvx/dotenvx">dotenvx</a> to use variable expansion.</p>
<p>Reference and expand variables already on your machine for use in your .env file.</p>
<pre><code class="ini"><span class="hljs-comment"># .env</span>
<span class="hljs-attr">USERNAME</span>=<span class="hljs-string">"username"</span>
<span class="hljs-attr">DATABASE_URL</span>=<span class="hljs-string">"postgres://${USERNAME}@localhost/my_database"</span>
</code></pre>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-comment">// index.js</span>
<span class="hljs-built_in">console</span>.log(<span class="hljs-string">'DATABASE_URL'</span>, process.env.DATABASE_URL)
</code></pre>
<pre><code class="sh">$ dotenvx run --debug -- node index.js
[dotenvx@0.14.1] injecting env (2) from .env
DATABASE_URL postgres://username@localhost/my_database
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="command-substitution">
  <h3>
    <a href="#command-substitution" name="command-substitution" class="pilcrow"></a>
Command Substitution
  </h3>
</div>
<p>Use <a href="https://github.com/dotenvx/dotenvx">dotenvx</a> to use command substitution.</p>
<p>Add the output of a command to one of your variables in your .env file.</p>
<pre><code class="ini"><span class="hljs-comment"># .env</span>
<span class="hljs-attr">DATABASE_URL</span>=<span class="hljs-string">"postgres://$(whoami)@localhost/my_database"</span>
</code></pre>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-comment">// index.js</span>
<span class="hljs-built_in">console</span>.log(<span class="hljs-string">'DATABASE_URL'</span>, process.env.DATABASE_URL)
</code></pre>
<pre><code class="sh">$ dotenvx run --debug -- node index.js
[dotenvx@0.14.1] injecting env (1) from .env
DATABASE_URL postgres://yourusername@localhost/my_database
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="syncing">
  <h3>
    <a href="#syncing" name="syncing" class="pilcrow"></a>
Syncing
  </h3>
</div>
<p>You need to keep <code>.env</code> files in sync between machines, environments, or team members? Use <a href="https://github.com/dotenvx/dotenvx">dotenvx</a> to encrypt your <code>.env</code> files and safely include them in source control. This still subscribes to the twelve-factor app rules by generating a decryption key separate from code.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="multiple-environments">
  <h3>
    <a href="#multiple-environments" name="multiple-environments" class="pilcrow"></a>
Multiple Environments
  </h3>
</div>
<p>Use <a href="https://github.com/dotenvx/dotenvx">dotenvx</a> to generate <code>.env.ci</code>, <code>.env.production</code> files, and more.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="deploying">
  <h3>
    <a href="#deploying" name="deploying" class="pilcrow"></a>
Deploying
  </h3>
</div>
<p>You need to deploy your secrets in a cloud-agnostic manner? Use <a href="https://github.com/dotenvx/dotenvx">dotenvx</a> to generate a private decryption key that is set on your production server.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="manage-multiple-environments">
  <h2>
    <a href="#manage-multiple-environments" name="manage-multiple-environments" class="pilcrow"></a>
üå¥ Manage Multiple Environments
  </h2>
</div>
<p>Use <a href="https://github.com/dotenvx/dotenvx">dotenvx</a></p>
<p>Run any environment locally. Create a <code>.env.ENVIRONMENT</code> file and use <code>--env-file</code> to load it. It's straightforward, yet flexible.</p>
<pre><code class="bash">$ <span class="hljs-built_in">echo</span> <span class="hljs-string">"HELLO=production"</span> &gt; .env.production
$ <span class="hljs-built_in">echo</span> <span class="hljs-string">"console.log('Hello ' + process.env.HELLO)"</span> &gt; index.js

$ dotenvx run --env-file=.env.production -- node index.js
Hello production
&gt; ^^
</code></pre>
<p>or with multiple .env files</p>
<pre><code class="bash">$ <span class="hljs-built_in">echo</span> <span class="hljs-string">"HELLO=local"</span> &gt; .env.local
$ <span class="hljs-built_in">echo</span> <span class="hljs-string">"HELLO=World"</span> &gt; .env
$ <span class="hljs-built_in">echo</span> <span class="hljs-string">"console.log('Hello ' + process.env.HELLO)"</span> &gt; index.js

$ dotenvx run --env-file=.env.local --env-file=.env -- node index.js
Hello <span class="hljs-built_in">local</span>
</code></pre>
<p><a href="https://dotenvx.com/docs/quickstart/environments">more environment examples</a></p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="deploying-1">
  <h2>
    <a href="#deploying-1" name="deploying-1" class="pilcrow"></a>
üöÄ Deploying
  </h2>
</div>
<p>Use <a href="https://github.com/dotenvx/dotenvx">dotenvx</a>.</p>
<p>Add encryption to your <code>.env</code> files with a single command. Pass the <code>--encrypt</code> flag.</p>
<pre><code>$ dotenvx set HELLO Production --encrypt -f .env.production
$ echo &quot;console.log('Hello ' + process.env.HELLO)&quot; &gt; index.js

$ DOTENV_PRIVATE_KEY_PRODUCTION=&quot;&lt;.env.production private key&gt;&quot; dotenvx run -- node index.js
[dotenvx] injecting env (2) from .env.production
Hello Production
</code></pre>
<p><a href="https://github.com/dotenvx/dotenvx?tab=readme-ov-file#encryption">learn more</a></p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="examples">
  <h2>
    <a href="#examples" name="examples" class="pilcrow"></a>
üìö Examples
  </h2>
</div>
<p>See <a href="https://github.com/dotenv-org/examples">examples</a> of using dotenv with various frameworks, languages, and configurations.</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://github.com/dotenv-org/examples/tree/master/usage/dotenv-nodejs">nodejs</a></li>
<li><a href="https://github.com/dotenv-org/examples/tree/master/usage/dotenv-nodejs-debug">nodejs (debug on)</a></li>
<li><a href="https://github.com/dotenv-org/examples/tree/master/usage/dotenv-nodejs-override">nodejs (override on)</a></li>
<li><a href="https://github.com/dotenv-org/examples/tree/master/usage/dotenv-custom-target">nodejs (processEnv override)</a></li>
<li><a href="https://github.com/dotenv-org/examples/tree/master/usage/dotenv-esm">esm</a></li>
<li><a href="https://github.com/dotenv-org/examples/tree/master/usage/dotenv-esm-preload">esm (preload)</a></li>
<li><a href="https://github.com/dotenv-org/examples/tree/master/usage/dotenv-typescript">typescript</a></li>
<li><a href="https://github.com/dotenv-org/examples/tree/master/usage/dotenv-typescript-parse">typescript parse</a></li>
<li><a href="https://github.com/dotenv-org/examples/tree/master/usage/dotenv-typescript-config">typescript config</a></li>
<li><a href="https://github.com/dotenv-org/examples/tree/master/usage/dotenv-webpack">webpack</a></li>
<li><a href="https://github.com/dotenv-org/examples/tree/master/usage/dotenv-webpack2">webpack (plugin)</a></li>
<li><a href="https://github.com/dotenv-org/examples/tree/master/usage/dotenv-react">react</a></li>
<li><a href="https://github.com/dotenv-org/examples/tree/master/usage/dotenv-react-typescript">react (typescript)</a></li>
<li><a href="https://github.com/dotenv-org/examples/tree/master/usage/dotenv-express">express</a></li>
<li><a href="https://github.com/dotenv-org/examples/tree/master/usage/dotenv-nestjs">nestjs</a></li>
<li><a href="https://github.com/dotenv-org/examples/tree/master/usage/dotenv-fastify">fastify</a></li>
</ul>
<div class="pilwrap" id="documentation">
  <h2>
    <a href="#documentation" name="documentation" class="pilcrow"></a>
üìñ Documentation
  </h2>
</div>
<p>Dotenv exposes four functions:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>config</code></li>
<li><code>parse</code></li>
<li><code>populate</code></li>
</ul>
<div class="pilwrap" id="config">
  <h3>
    <a href="#config" name="config" class="pilcrow"></a>
Config
  </h3>
</div>
<p><code>config</code> will read your <code>.env</code> file, parse the contents, assign it to
<a href="https://nodejs.org/docs/latest/api/process.html#process_process_env"><code>process.env</code></a>,
and return an Object with a <code>parsed</code> key containing the loaded content or an <code>error</code> key if it failed.</p>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> result = dotenv.config()

<span class="hljs-keyword">if</span> (result.error) {
  <span class="hljs-keyword">throw</span> result.error
}

<span class="hljs-built_in">console</span>.log(result.parsed)
</code></pre>
<p>You can additionally, pass options to <code>config</code>.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="options">
  <h4>
    <a href="#options" name="options" class="pilcrow"></a>
Options
  </h4>
</div>
<div class="pilwrap" id="path">
  <h5>
    <a href="#path" name="path" class="pilcrow"></a>
path
  </h5>
</div>
<p>Default: <code>path.resolve(process.cwd(), '.env')</code></p>
<p>Specify a custom path if your file containing environment variables is located elsewhere.</p>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-built_in">require</span>(<span class="hljs-string">'dotenv'</span>).config({ <span class="hljs-attr">path</span>: <span class="hljs-string">'/custom/path/to/.env'</span> })
</code></pre>
<p>By default, <code>config</code> will look for a file called .env in the current working directory.</p>
<p>Pass in multiple files as an array, and they will be parsed in order and combined with <code>process.env</code> (or <code>option.processEnv</code>, if set). The first value set for a variable will win, unless the <code>options.override</code> flag is set, in which case the last value set will win.  If a value already exists in <code>process.env</code> and the <code>options.override</code> flag is NOT set, no changes will be made to that value.</p>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-built_in">require</span>(<span class="hljs-string">'dotenv'</span>).config({ <span class="hljs-attr">path</span>: [<span class="hljs-string">'.env.local'</span>, <span class="hljs-string">'.env'</span>] })
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="quiet">
  <h5>
    <a href="#quiet" name="quiet" class="pilcrow"></a>
quiet
  </h5>
</div>
<p>Default: <code>false</code></p>
<p>Suppress runtime logging message.</p>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-comment">// index.js</span>
<span class="hljs-built_in">require</span>(<span class="hljs-string">'dotenv'</span>).config({ <span class="hljs-attr">quiet</span>: <span class="hljs-literal">false</span> }) <span class="hljs-comment">// change to true to suppress</span>
<span class="hljs-built_in">console</span>.log(<span class="hljs-string">`Hello <span class="hljs-subst">${process.env.HELLO}</span>`</span>)
</code></pre>
<pre><code class="ini"># .env
.env
</code></pre>
<pre><code class="sh">$ node index.js
[dotenv@17.0.0] injecting env (1) from .env
Hello World
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="encoding">
  <h5>
    <a href="#encoding" name="encoding" class="pilcrow"></a>
encoding
  </h5>
</div>
<p>Default: <code>utf8</code></p>
<p>Specify the encoding of your file containing environment variables.</p>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-built_in">require</span>(<span class="hljs-string">'dotenv'</span>).config({ <span class="hljs-attr">encoding</span>: <span class="hljs-string">'latin1'</span> })
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="debug">
  <h5>
    <a href="#debug" name="debug" class="pilcrow"></a>
debug
  </h5>
</div>
<p>Default: <code>false</code></p>
<p>Turn on logging to help debug why certain keys or values are not being set as you expect.</p>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-built_in">require</span>(<span class="hljs-string">'dotenv'</span>).config({ <span class="hljs-attr">debug</span>: process.env.DEBUG })
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="override">
  <h5>
    <a href="#override" name="override" class="pilcrow"></a>
override
  </h5>
</div>
<p>Default: <code>false</code></p>
<p>Override any environment variables that have already been set on your machine with values from your .env file(s). If multiple files have been provided in <code>option.path</code> the override will also be used as each file is combined with the next. Without <code>override</code> being set, the first value wins. With <code>override</code> set the last value wins.</p>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-built_in">require</span>(<span class="hljs-string">'dotenv'</span>).config({ <span class="hljs-attr">override</span>: <span class="hljs-literal">true</span> })
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="processenv">
  <h5>
    <a href="#processenv" name="processenv" class="pilcrow"></a>
processEnv
  </h5>
</div>
<p>Default: <code>process.env</code></p>
<p>Specify an object to write your environment variables to. Defaults to <code>process.env</code> environment variables.</p>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> myObject = {}
<span class="hljs-built_in">require</span>(<span class="hljs-string">'dotenv'</span>).config({ <span class="hljs-attr">processEnv</span>: myObject })

<span class="hljs-built_in">console</span>.log(myObject) <span class="hljs-comment">// values from .env</span>
<span class="hljs-built_in">console</span>.log(process.env) <span class="hljs-comment">// this was not changed or written to</span>
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="parse">
  <h3>
    <a href="#parse" name="parse" class="pilcrow"></a>
Parse
  </h3>
</div>
<p>The engine which parses the contents of your file containing environment
variables is available to use. It accepts a String or Buffer and will return
an Object with the parsed keys and values.</p>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> dotenv = <span class="hljs-built_in">require</span>(<span class="hljs-string">'dotenv'</span>)
<span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> buf = Buffer.from(<span class="hljs-string">'BASIC=basic'</span>)
<span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> config = dotenv.parse(buf) <span class="hljs-comment">// will return an object</span>
<span class="hljs-built_in">console</span>.log(<span class="hljs-keyword">typeof</span> config, config) <span class="hljs-comment">// object { BASIC : 'basic' }</span>
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="options-1">
  <h4>
    <a href="#options-1" name="options-1" class="pilcrow"></a>
Options
  </h4>
</div>
<div class="pilwrap" id="debug-1">
  <h5>
    <a href="#debug-1" name="debug-1" class="pilcrow"></a>
debug
  </h5>
</div>
<p>Default: <code>false</code></p>
<p>Turn on logging to help debug why certain keys or values are not being set as you expect.</p>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> dotenv = <span class="hljs-built_in">require</span>(<span class="hljs-string">'dotenv'</span>)
<span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> buf = Buffer.from(<span class="hljs-string">'hello world'</span>)
<span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> opt = { <span class="hljs-attr">debug</span>: <span class="hljs-literal">true</span> }
<span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> config = dotenv.parse(buf, opt)
<span class="hljs-comment">// expect a debug message because the buffer is not in KEY=VAL form</span>
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="populate">
  <h3>
    <a href="#populate" name="populate" class="pilcrow"></a>
Populate
  </h3>
</div>
<p>The engine which populates the contents of your .env file to <code>process.env</code> is available for use. It accepts a target, a source, and options. This is useful for power users who want to supply their own objects.</p>
<p>For example, customizing the source:</p>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> dotenv = <span class="hljs-built_in">require</span>(<span class="hljs-string">'dotenv'</span>)
<span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> parsed = { <span class="hljs-attr">HELLO</span>: <span class="hljs-string">'world'</span> }

dotenv.populate(process.env, parsed)

<span class="hljs-built_in">console</span>.log(process.env.HELLO) <span class="hljs-comment">// world</span>
</code></pre>
<p>For example, customizing the source AND target:</p>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> dotenv = <span class="hljs-built_in">require</span>(<span class="hljs-string">'dotenv'</span>)
<span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> parsed = { <span class="hljs-attr">HELLO</span>: <span class="hljs-string">'universe'</span> }
<span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> target = { <span class="hljs-attr">HELLO</span>: <span class="hljs-string">'world'</span> } <span class="hljs-comment">// empty object</span>

dotenv.populate(target, parsed, { <span class="hljs-attr">override</span>: <span class="hljs-literal">true</span>, <span class="hljs-attr">debug</span>: <span class="hljs-literal">true</span> })

<span class="hljs-built_in">console</span>.log(target) <span class="hljs-comment">// { HELLO: 'universe' }</span>
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="options-2">
  <h4>
    <a href="#options-2" name="options-2" class="pilcrow"></a>
options
  </h4>
</div>
<div class="pilwrap" id="debug-2">
  <h5>
    <a href="#debug-2" name="debug-2" class="pilcrow"></a>
Debug
  </h5>
</div>
<p>Default: <code>false</code></p>
<p>Turn on logging to help debug why certain keys or values are not being populated as you expect.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="override-1">
  <h5>
    <a href="#override-1" name="override-1" class="pilcrow"></a>
override
  </h5>
</div>
<p>Default: <code>false</code></p>
<p>Override any environment variables that have already been set.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="question-mark-ornament-faq">
  <h2>
    <a href="#question-mark-ornament-faq" name="question-mark-ornament-faq" class="pilcrow"></a>
‚ùì FAQ
  </h2>
</div>
<div class="pilwrap" id="why-is-the.env-file-not-loading-my-environment-variables-successfully">
  <h3>
    <a href="#why-is-the.env-file-not-loading-my-environment-variables-successfully" name="why-is-the.env-file-not-loading-my-environment-variables-successfully" class="pilcrow"></a>
Why is the <code>.env</code> file not loading my environment variables successfully?
  </h3>
</div>
<p>Most likely your <code>.env</code> file is not in the correct place. <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42335016/dotenv-file-is-not-loading-environment-variables">See this stack overflow</a>.</p>
<p>Turn on debug mode and try again..</p>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-built_in">require</span>(<span class="hljs-string">'dotenv'</span>).config({ <span class="hljs-attr">debug</span>: <span class="hljs-literal">true</span> })
</code></pre>
<p>You will receive a helpful error outputted to your console.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="should-i-commit-my.env-file">
  <h3>
    <a href="#should-i-commit-my.env-file" name="should-i-commit-my.env-file" class="pilcrow"></a>
Should I commit my <code>.env</code> file?
  </h3>
</div>
<p>No. We <strong>strongly</strong> recommend against committing your <code>.env</code> file to version
control. It should only include environment-specific values such as database
passwords or API keys. Your production database should have a different
password than your development database.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="should-i-have-multiple.env-files">
  <h3>
    <a href="#should-i-have-multiple.env-files" name="should-i-have-multiple.env-files" class="pilcrow"></a>
Should I have multiple <code>.env</code> files?
  </h3>
</div>
<p>We recommend creating one <code>.env</code> file per environment. Use <code>.env</code> for local/development, <code>.env.production</code> for production and so on. This still follows the twelve factor principles as each is attributed individually to its own environment. Avoid custom set ups that work in inheritance somehow (<code>.env.production</code> inherits values form <code>.env</code> for example). It is better to duplicate values if necessary across each <code>.env.environment</code> file.</p>
<blockquote>
<p>In a twelve-factor app, env vars are granular controls, each fully orthogonal to other env vars. They are never grouped together as ‚Äúenvironments‚Äù, but instead are independently managed for each deploy. This is a model that scales up smoothly as the app naturally expands into more deploys over its lifetime.</p>
<p>‚Äì <a href="http://12factor.net/config">The Twelve-Factor App</a></p>
</blockquote>
<div class="pilwrap" id="what-rules-does-the-parsing-engine-follow">
  <h3>
    <a href="#what-rules-does-the-parsing-engine-follow" name="what-rules-does-the-parsing-engine-follow" class="pilcrow"></a>
What rules does the parsing engine follow?
  </h3>
</div>
<p>The parsing engine currently supports the following rules:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>BASIC=basic</code> becomes <code>{BASIC: 'basic'}</code></li>
<li>empty lines are skipped</li>
<li>lines beginning with <code>#</code> are treated as comments</li>
<li><code>#</code> marks the beginning of a comment (unless when the value is wrapped in quotes)</li>
<li>empty values become empty strings (<code>EMPTY=</code> becomes <code>{EMPTY: ''}</code>)</li>
<li>inner quotes are maintained (think JSON) (<code>JSON={&quot;foo&quot;: &quot;bar&quot;}</code> becomes <code>{JSON:&quot;{\&quot;foo\&quot;: \&quot;bar\&quot;}&quot;</code>)</li>
<li>whitespace is removed from both ends of unquoted values (see more on <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/Trim"><code>trim</code></a>) (<code>FOO= some value</code> becomes <code>{FOO: 'some value'}</code>)</li>
<li>single and double quoted values are escaped (<code>SINGLE_QUOTE='quoted'</code> becomes <code>{SINGLE_QUOTE: &quot;quoted&quot;}</code>)</li>
<li>single and double quoted values maintain whitespace from both ends (<code>FOO=&quot; some value &quot;</code> becomes <code>{FOO: ' some value '}</code>)</li>
<li>double quoted values expand new lines (<code>MULTILINE=&quot;new\nline&quot;</code> becomes</li>
</ul>
<pre><code>{MULTILINE: 'new
line'}
</code></pre>
<ul>
<li>backticks are supported (<code>BACKTICK_KEY=`This has 'single' and &quot;double&quot; quotes inside of it.`</code>)</li>
</ul>
<div class="pilwrap" id="what-happens-to-environment-variables-that-were-already-set">
  <h3>
    <a href="#what-happens-to-environment-variables-that-were-already-set" name="what-happens-to-environment-variables-that-were-already-set" class="pilcrow"></a>
What happens to environment variables that were already set?
  </h3>
</div>
<p>By default, we will never modify any environment variables that have already been set. In particular, if there is a variable in your <code>.env</code> file which collides with one that already exists in your environment, then that variable will be skipped.</p>
<p>If instead, you want to override <code>process.env</code> use the <code>override</code> option.</p>
<pre><code class="javascript"><span class="hljs-built_in">require</span>(<span class="hljs-string">'dotenv'</span>).config({ <span class="hljs-attr">override</span>: <span class="hljs-literal">true</span> })
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="how-come-my-environment-variables-are-not-showing-up-for-react">
  <h3>
    <a href="#how-come-my-environment-variables-are-not-showing-up-for-react" name="how-come-my-environment-variables-are-not-showing-up-for-react" class="pilcrow"></a>
How come my environment variables are not showing up for React?
  </h3>
</div>
<p>Your React code is run in Webpack, where the <code>fs</code> module or even the <code>process</code> global itself are not accessible out-of-the-box. <code>process.env</code> can only be injected through Webpack configuration.</p>
<p>If you are using <a href="https://www.npmjs.com/package/react-scripts"><code>react-scripts</code></a>, which is distributed through <a href="https://create-react-app.dev/"><code>create-react-app</code></a>, it has dotenv built in but with a quirk. Preface your environment variables with <code>REACT_APP_</code>. See <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42182577/is-it-possible-to-use-dotenv-in-a-react-project">this stack overflow</a> for more details.</p>
<p>If you are using other frameworks (e.g. Next.js, Gatsby...), you need to consult their documentation for how to inject environment variables into the client.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="can-i-customizewrite-plugins-for-dotenv">
  <h3>
    <a href="#can-i-customizewrite-plugins-for-dotenv" name="can-i-customizewrite-plugins-for-dotenv" class="pilcrow"></a>
Can I customize/write plugins for dotenv?
  </h3>
</div>
<p>Yes! <code>dotenv.config()</code> returns an object representing the parsed <code>.env</code> file. This gives you everything you need to continue setting values on <code>process.env</code>. For example:</p>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> dotenv = <span class="hljs-built_in">require</span>(<span class="hljs-string">'dotenv'</span>)
<span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> variableExpansion = <span class="hljs-built_in">require</span>(<span class="hljs-string">'dotenv-expand'</span>)
<span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> myEnv = dotenv.config()
variableExpansion(myEnv)
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="how-do-i-use-dotenv-with-import">
  <h3>
    <a href="#how-do-i-use-dotenv-with-import" name="how-do-i-use-dotenv-with-import" class="pilcrow"></a>
How do I use dotenv with <code>import</code>?
  </h3>
</div>
<p>Simply..</p>
<pre><code class="javascript"><span class="hljs-comment">// index.mjs (ESM)</span>
<span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> <span class="hljs-string">'dotenv/config'</span> <span class="hljs-comment">// see https://github.com/motdotla/dotenv#how-do-i-use-dotenv-with-import</span>
<span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> express <span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> <span class="hljs-string">'express'</span>
</code></pre>
<p>A little background..</p>
<blockquote>
<p>When you run a module containing an <code>import</code> declaration, the modules it imports are loaded first, then each module body is executed in a depth-first traversal of the dependency graph, avoiding cycles by skipping anything already executed.</p>
<p>‚Äì <a href="https://hacks.mozilla.org/2015/08/es6-in-depth-modules/">ES6 In Depth: Modules</a></p>
</blockquote>
<p>What does this mean in plain language? It means you would think the following would work but it won't.</p>
<p><code>errorReporter.mjs</code>:</p>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-class"><span class="hljs-keyword">class</span> <span class="hljs-title">Client</span> </span>{
  <span class="hljs-keyword">constructor</span> (apiKey) {
    <span class="hljs-built_in">console</span>.log(<span class="hljs-string">'apiKey'</span>, apiKey)

    <span class="hljs-keyword">this</span>.apiKey = apiKey
  }
}

<span class="hljs-keyword">export</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">default</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">new</span> Client(process.env.API_KEY)
</code></pre>
<p><code>index.mjs</code>:</p>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-comment">// Note: this is INCORRECT and will not work</span>
<span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> * <span class="hljs-keyword">as</span> dotenv <span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> <span class="hljs-string">'dotenv'</span>
dotenv.config()

<span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> errorReporter <span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> <span class="hljs-string">'./errorReporter.mjs'</span> <span class="hljs-comment">// process.env.API_KEY will be blank!</span>
</code></pre>
<p><code>process.env.API_KEY</code> will be blank.</p>
<p>Instead, <code>index.mjs</code> should be written as..</p>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> <span class="hljs-string">'dotenv/config'</span>

<span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> errorReporter <span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> <span class="hljs-string">'./errorReporter.mjs'</span>
</code></pre>
<p>Does that make sense? It's a bit unintuitive, but it is how importing of ES6 modules work. Here is a <a href="https://github.com/dotenv-org/examples/tree/master/usage/dotenv-es6-import-pitfall">working example of this pitfall</a>.</p>
<p>There are two alternatives to this approach:</p>
<ol>
<li>Preload with dotenvx: <code>dotenvx run -- node index.js</code> (<em>Note: you do not need to <code>import</code> dotenv with this approach</em>)</li>
<li>Create a separate file that will execute <code>config</code> first as outlined in <a href="https://github.com/motdotla/dotenv/issues/133#issuecomment-255298822">this comment on #133</a></li>
</ol>
<div class="pilwrap" id="why-am-i-getting-the-error-module-not-found-error-cant-resolve-cryptoorosorpath">
  <h3>
    <a href="#why-am-i-getting-the-error-module-not-found-error-cant-resolve-cryptoorosorpath" name="why-am-i-getting-the-error-module-not-found-error-cant-resolve-cryptoorosorpath" class="pilcrow"></a>
Why am I getting the error <code>Module not found: Error: Can't resolve 'crypto|os|path'</code>?
  </h3>
</div>
<p>You are using dotenv on the front-end and have not included a polyfill. Webpack &lt; 5 used to include these for you. Do the following:</p>
<pre><code class="bash">npm install node-polyfill-webpack-plugin
</code></pre>
<p>Configure your <code>webpack.config.js</code> to something like the following.</p>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-built_in">require</span>(<span class="hljs-string">'dotenv'</span>).config()

<span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> path = <span class="hljs-built_in">require</span>(<span class="hljs-string">'path'</span>);
<span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> webpack = <span class="hljs-built_in">require</span>(<span class="hljs-string">'webpack'</span>)

<span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> NodePolyfillPlugin = <span class="hljs-built_in">require</span>(<span class="hljs-string">'node-polyfill-webpack-plugin'</span>)

<span class="hljs-built_in">module</span>.exports = {
  <span class="hljs-attr">mode</span>: <span class="hljs-string">'development'</span>,
  <span class="hljs-attr">entry</span>: <span class="hljs-string">'./src/index.ts'</span>,
  <span class="hljs-attr">output</span>: {
    <span class="hljs-attr">filename</span>: <span class="hljs-string">'bundle.js'</span>,
    <span class="hljs-attr">path</span>: path.resolve(__dirname, <span class="hljs-string">'dist'</span>),
  },
  <span class="hljs-attr">plugins</span>: [
    <span class="hljs-keyword">new</span> NodePolyfillPlugin(),
    <span class="hljs-keyword">new</span> webpack.DefinePlugin({
      <span class="hljs-string">'process.env'</span>: {
        <span class="hljs-attr">HELLO</span>: <span class="hljs-built_in">JSON</span>.stringify(process.env.HELLO)
      }
    }),
  ]
};
</code></pre>
<p>Alternatively, just use <a href="https://github.com/mrsteele/dotenv-webpack">dotenv-webpack</a> which does this and more behind the scenes for you.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="what-about-variable-expansion">
  <h3>
    <a href="#what-about-variable-expansion" name="what-about-variable-expansion" class="pilcrow"></a>
What about variable expansion?
  </h3>
</div>
<p>Try <a href="https://github.com/motdotla/dotenv-expand">dotenv-expand</a></p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="what-about-syncing-and-securing.env-files">
  <h3>
    <a href="#what-about-syncing-and-securing.env-files" name="what-about-syncing-and-securing.env-files" class="pilcrow"></a>
What about syncing and securing .env files?
  </h3>
</div>
<p>Use <a href="https://github.com/dotenvx/dotenvx">dotenvx</a> to unlock syncing encrypted .env files over git.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="what-if-i-accidentally-commit-my.env-file-to-code">
  <h3>
    <a href="#what-if-i-accidentally-commit-my.env-file-to-code" name="what-if-i-accidentally-commit-my.env-file-to-code" class="pilcrow"></a>
What if I accidentally commit my <code>.env</code> file to code?
  </h3>
</div>
<p>Remove it, <a href="https://docs.github.com/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-and-data-secure/removing-sensitive-data-from-a-repository">remove git history</a> and then install the <a href="https://github.com/dotenvx/dotenvx#pre-commit">git pre-commit hook</a> to prevent this from ever happening again.</p>
<pre><code>brew install dotenvx/brew/dotenvx
dotenvx precommit --install
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="how-can-i-prevent-committing-my.env-file-to-a-docker-build">
  <h3>
    <a href="#how-can-i-prevent-committing-my.env-file-to-a-docker-build" name="how-can-i-prevent-committing-my.env-file-to-a-docker-build" class="pilcrow"></a>
How can I prevent committing my <code>.env</code> file to a Docker build?
  </h3>
</div>
<p>Use the <a href="https://dotenvx.com/docs/features/prebuild">docker prebuild hook</a>.</p>
<pre><code class="bash"><span class="hljs-comment"># Dockerfile</span>
...
RUN curl -fsS https://dotenvx.sh/ | sh
...
RUN dotenvx prebuild
CMD [<span class="hljs-string">"dotenvx"</span>, <span class="hljs-string">"run"</span>, <span class="hljs-string">"--"</span>, <span class="hljs-string">"node"</span>, <span class="hljs-string">"index.js"</span>]
</code></pre>

    <a href="#contributing-guide" name="contributing-guide" class="pilcrow"></a>
Contributing Guide
  </h2>
</div>

<div class="pilwrap" id="whos-using-dotenv">
  <h2>
    <a href="#whos-using-dotenv" name="whos-using-dotenv" class="pilcrow"></a>
Who's using dotenv?
  </h2>
</div>
<p><a href="https://www.npmjs.com/browse/depended/dotenv">These npm modules depend on it.</a></p>
<p>Projects that expand it often use the <a href="https://www.npmjs.com/search?q=keywords:dotenv">keyword &quot;dotenv&quot; on npm</a>.</p>
</div>
  </div>
